doc.title: The People's Bank of China (PBOC) has kept interbank liquidity ample in recent months, partially assisting the liquidity- driven equity rally. M1 growth has climbed meaningfully since late last year,
doc.source_uri: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/GS/Liquidity and Inﬂation Redux – A Roundup of China’s Monetary Policy Stance (Chen)_2025-09-01

processing_metadata.publication: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/GS
processing_metadata.input_relative_path: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/GS

passages.text: The People's Bank of China (PBOC) has kept interbank liquidity ample in recent months, partially assisting the liquidity- driven equity rally. M1 growth has climbed meaningfully since late last year, which, combined with anti- involution policies to reduce excessive price- cutting, has fueled reflation hopes. At the same time, central bank communications appear to have turned less dovish. In this note, we analyze the drivers of the recent rise in M1 growth, assess the PBOC's monetary policy stance, and discuss their implications for China rates and FX.

Faster M1 growth signals reduced deflationary risks in China, but the magnitude of reflation may be smaller than implied by historical correlations. The rebound in M1 growth over the past 12 months largely reflects a one- off drop in corporate demand deposits in mid- 2024, driven by tighter regulations on banks' interest compensation practices. In addition, part of the rise in M1 growth comes from households shifting from time to demand deposits amid much lower deposit rates. Without significant improvements in corporates' desire to invest and households' willingness to consume, M1 growth may stop accelerating or even moderate after base effects fade and PPI deflation is likely to continue next year.

China's monetary policy stance remains accommodative, with ample interbank liquidity and accelerating credit growth. That said, less dovish policy signals point to little intention for near- term, high- profile easing, such as policy rate or RRR cuts. At the core of the stance is the PBOC's perpetual balancing act between financial stability and growth support. With real GDP growth on track for the \(5\%\) target, policymakers are in no rush to deliver significant easing, while protecting banks' net interest margins remains important to safeguarding financial stability. Though Fed rate cuts could open the door, the PBOC would likely follow only if economic weakness puts the \(5\%\) target at risk. Our baseline is a dual cut in Q4 (a 10bp policy rate cut and a 50bp RRR cut), when year- over- year growth decelerates sharply towards \(4\%\) on last year's high base. This remains a close call given lack of urgency for policymakers.

On market implications for China rates, our models suggest \(1.8\%\) as the fair value anchor for 10y CGB yields over the next 12 months. Deflationary pressures may lessen somewhat on policy interventions, but slower growth and semiannual 10bp rate cuts that we expect will offset the upward pressures on yields. Even with further bond- to- equity rotation, we see ceilings of \(2.2\%\) for 10y
CGB and \(2.5\%\) for 30y CGB, with asset- liability management demand limiting the rise of yields.

Regarding USD/CNY, we see the unusual appreciation bias in the PBOC's daily fixing as a policy push to guide CNY gradually stronger. Deeply negative carry has discouraged investors from going long CNY, leaving the CNY underperforming peers. This pre- emptive move by the PBOC should help the CNY catch up with peers and reduce the risk of a sharp appreciation later. We expect onshore and offshore spot to converge toward the fixing, with USD/CNY reaching 7.0 by year end.

The anti- involution policies that are the most recent liquidity- driven equity market rally have put the liquidity- inflation link back in focus. Investors view accelerating money and credit growth as leading indicators of potential inflation in China, expecting at least some relief in deflation in the coming months. We agree base effects may help, but the demand outlook remains the key to a sustained PPI reflation. In this note, we review the relationship between money supply and inflation in China, analyze the recent rise in M1 growth, and assess the monetary policy stance with its market implications.

Money and credit growth are often viewed as leading indicators for economic activity and inflation. While their correlation with growth and inflation has weakened somewhat in recent years, they remain useful for directional forecasting. Both money and credit indicators have showed a notable rebound recently. Total social financing (TSF) growth has recovered from a trough of \(78\%\) yoy last October to \(9.0\%\) yoy in July, largely due to strong government bond net issuance. M1 growth, commonly regarded as a proxy for corporate and household willingness to spend, also accelerated to \(5.6\%\) yoy in July, up from \(- 3.3\%\) yoy last September (Exhibit 1). Faster M1 growth points to easing PPI deflation ahead (Exhibit 2). While M1 remains a reliable 12- month lead indicator on major inflation measures, we expect only gradual acceleration in inflation, with PPI deflation likely to persist into 2026. PPI inflation may not turn positive until early 2027, in our view. The rationale for this divergence lies in the drivers of M1 growth.
Exhibit 1: M1 growth has accelerated notably since late 2024
Exhibit 2: Rising M1 growth points to easing PPI deflation in the coming months
M1 series based on new definition prior to 2024 are GS estimates. The PBOC only published 2024- 25 data. New M1 = Old M1 + household demand deposits + reserve funds of non- bank payment institutions.

The dashed line denotes GS forecasts of PPI inflation. Here we use the old definition of M1 to retain a longer historical series, but its correlation with PPI inflation is similar under the new definition.
Source: Wind, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Source: Wind, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
M1 consists of cash in circulation (M0), demand deposits, and provisions held by non- bank payment institutions. Demand deposits account for the majority of M1 (86%),

while provisions make up only about \(2\%\) . Cash in circulation accounts for around \(12\%\) of M1, but its contribution to year- over- year growth is steady and not a key driver of changes in M1 growth. Demand deposits come from households, non- financial corporates, and government related organizations (机关团体).1 While household and corporate deposits could serve as a barometer of private sectors' willingness to spend, government- related deposits mainly reflect the pace of fiscal expenditure.

The rebound in M1 growth over the past 12 months has mainly reflected swings in non- financial corporate demand deposit growth (Exhibit 3). The level of these deposits declined sharply from Q1 to Q2 2024 (before recovering in Q4 after the government's September policy pivot), primarily as regulators tightened curbs on manual interest compensation (top- ups that effectively raised deposit rates; 手工补息) used by banks to compete for deposits.2 This regulatory effect was largely a one- off adjustment to deposit levels, but it introduced significant base effects into the year- over- year growth.3 With the base 12 months ago lower, year- over- year growth should be stronger even without sequential gains. We estimate about 60bp of the 1pp rise in M1 growth this July came from base effects. Exhibit 4 shows demand deposit levels as a percent deviation from trend- implied values.4 After a sharp drop in Q2 2024, corporate demand deposits have recovered modestly but remain \(20\%\) below trend- implied levels. Without meaningful sequential gains, the recent acceleration in M1 growth will be difficult to sustain.
Exhibit 3: The rise in M1 growth is primarily driven by non-financial corporate demand deposits
Source:CEIC,GoldmanSachsGlobal InvestmentResearch
Exhibit 4: Corporate demand deposits remain well below trend-implied levels
Source:CEIC,GoldmanSachsGlobal InvestmentResearch
Two additional factors contributed to the 3.3pp rise in year- over- year M1 growth over the past two months: fiscal spending (1.3pp from government- related deposits) and

households reallocating from time deposits to demand deposits (0.8pp). The large volume of government bond issuance has masked a faster pace of fiscal spending in the fiscal deposit data compared with a year ago. Exhibit 5 shows that, after excluding government bond net issuance, changes in fiscal deposits indicate an acceleration in fiscal spending in June and July. In addition, time deposit rates have fallen materially in recent years. For example, the 3- year deposit rate is now \(1.25\%\) , 150bp lower than three years ago, which may have prompted households to shift from time deposits to demand deposits (Exhibit 6). While faster fiscal spending should support domestic demand and inflation, household deposit reallocation may instead flow into financial markets, not necessarily signaling stronger consumption.
Exhibit 5: Fiscal spending has increased on a year-over-year basis in the recent two months
Source: CEIC, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 6: A sharp decline of time deposit rates likely prompted the shifts into demand deposits
The shaded areas highlight the deposit rate cuts following policy rate cuts. Here we use deposit rates from the six largest SOE banks.

China's monetary policy stance remains accommodative, with flush interbank liquidity and accelerating M2 and TSF growth. Interbank repo rates are hovering around the OMO target, well below levels seen in January- April, when efforts to cool down the bond rally and FX depreciation pressures had pushed repo rates about 30bp above the OMO target (Exhibit 7). That said, we have noticed the PBOC's less dovish tone in recent communications, implying little intention to pursue near- term, high- profile easing measures, such as policy rate cuts, RRR cuts, or renewed CGB purchases. At the core of the current stance is the central bank's perpetual balancing act between financial stability and growth support. With real GDP growth broadly on track to meet the \(5\%\) target, policymakers appear in no rush to deliver significant easing. Protecting banks' net interest margins remains important to financial stability, raising the bar for policy rate cuts. Though Fed rate cuts could open the door, the PBOC would likely follow only if economic weakness puts the \(5\%\) target at risk. Our baseline expectation is a dual cut in Q4 (a 10bp policy rate cut and a 50bp RRR cut), when year- over- year growth decelerates sharply towards \(4\%\) on last year's high base. This remains a close call given lack of urgency for policymakers.
China's government bond yield curve has bear steepened over the past two months, due to reflation hopes and bond- to- equity rotation. Short- term rates remain anchored by

ample interbank liquidity, while longer- dated CGB yields have risen 15- 30bp. China rates were underperforming equities in both absolute and volatility- adjusted return terms. Therefore, typical CGB buyers, such as mutual funds with mixed mandates, appear to have reallocated into equities in pursuit of better performance. That said, we do not expect an open- ended climb: our valuation models, incorporating growth/inflation expectations and liquidity conditions, suggest long- term yields are nearing resistance levels. Our baseline economic forecasts suggest \(1.8\%\) as the fair- value anchor for 10y CGB yields over the next 12 months (Exhibit 8). We expect CPI inflation to gradually normalize to \(1.5\%\) yoy over the next 2- 3 years, adding upward pressure on CGB yields. But slower growth and semiannual 10bp policy rate cuts that we expect should offset the upward pressures from inflation.
Exhibit 7: Interbank repo rates are hovering near the OMO target
Source: CEIC, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 8: 10y CGB yields have risen towards the "fair value" implied by macro fundamentals and current liquidity conditions
We calibrate a simple OLS model to examine the drivers of CGB yields, including 1-year ahead growth/inflation forecast, 10y UST yield, and the spread between OMO target and 7d repo fixing.
Source: CEIC, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

Even if bond- to- stock rotation continues, we expect long- term yields to stabilize at certain levels, as regulators are likely to step in to curb abrupt moves and contain CGB issuance costs. To gauge the likely ceiling for 10y and 30y CGBs, we reference the 2023 average of the 10y CGB - OMO target spread (80bp) and the 10s30s slope (30bp), when reopening and policy support hopes helped reduce pessimism on China's economy. These spreads suggest potential ceilings of around \(2.2\%\) for 10y and \(2.5\%\) for 30y CGB yields in the event of another sharp bond- to- stock rotation. Higher yields are also seen as attractive for banks' and insurers' asset- liability management demand.

The sharp CNY appreciation against the USD drew significant market attention last week, with USD/CNY spot down \(0.9\%\) to below 7.13. A roughly 300pips decline in the fixing suggests a policy push behind the move (Exhibit 9). In our view, the lower fix reflects two factors: 1) broad USD weakness from July to August amid expectations of a dovish Fed (DXY fell from 100 to below 98), and 2) pre- emptive management of USD/CNY to gradually ease appreciation pressures. Despite supportive fundamentals (such as record- high trade surplus), wide US- China interest rate differentials discourage investors from going long CNY and drove the underperformance versus peers. Investors may need a clear catalyst to take long CNY positions against the USD. The continued

lower USD/CNY fixings amid a relatively stable Dollar may serve as such a catalyst, prompting catch- up with other currencies. Beyond policy support, two additional drivers stand out: 1) a rise in the FX conversion ratio, suggesting exporters are settling more FX or hedge risks more actively; 2) equity market gains attracting inflows through channels such as Stock Connect. In addition, CNY appreciation may be a goodwill gesture from the Chinese government amid ongoing trade talks with the US. Looking ahead, we expect onshore and offshore spot to converge towards the USD/CNY fixing, with USD/CNY spot reaching 7.0 by year- end.
Exhibit 9: An unusual appreciation bias in the USD/CNY fixing pushed the spot rate lower
Source: Bloomberg, Data compiled by Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

numerical_data.context: provisions held by non- bank payment institutions. Demand deposits account for the majority of M1 (86%),<｜end▁of▁sentence｜>
